title: 113_hr2399
content: The Act is titled the "Limiting Internet and Blanket Electronic Review of Telecommunications and Email Act" or "LIBERT-E Act." It includes reforms to access certain business records for foreign intelligence and international terrorism investigations. Section 501 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (50 U.S.C. 1861) is amended to require specific and articulable facts showing relevance to clandestine intelligence activities pertaining only to the individual under investigation. Subsection (c)(2) is also modified. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to require specific facts showing relevance to clandestine intelligence activities for individuals under investigation. Subsection (c)(2) is also modified to direct applicants to provide notice to persons required to produce tangible things under the order, informing them of their right to challenge the legality of the order by filing a petition. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to require specific facts showing relevance to clandestine intelligence activities for individuals under investigation. Subsection (c)(2) is also modified to direct applicants to provide notice to persons required to produce tangible things under the order, informing them of their right to challenge the legality of the order by filing a petition. In subsection (f)(2), amendments are made to include nondisclosure orders and streamline the language regarding production orders. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL DISCLOSURES TO CONGRESS AND THE PUBLIC. Section 601 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act is amended to include additional disclosures to Congress and the public, requiring the Attorney General to make reports, decisions, orders, opinions, pleadings, applications, or memoranda of law available to all Members of Congress within 45 days. The Attorney General must provide unclassified summaries of decisions, orders, or opinions within 180 days of submission. Additionally, all reports and documents submitted under Section 601 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act must be made available to Members of Congress within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General must provide unclassified summaries of decisions, orders, or opinions within 180 days of submission under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The Attorney General must provide unclassified summaries of decisions, orders, or opinions within 180 days under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Additionally, a report on the impact of provisions related to access to certain business records and targeting non-United States persons outside the US on the privacy of individuals in the US is required. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice and elements of the intelligence community must submit a joint report to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act. The report will assess the impact of acquisitions made under sections 501 and 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act on the privacy interests of United States persons. The joint report to Congress will assess the impact of acquisitions under sections 501 and 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act on the privacy of persons in the United States, including the number of persons whose communications have been acquired or reviewed. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice will review incidents of non-compliance with sections 501 and 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, focusing on recurring incidents and their impact on privacy. The report will be made public within 180 days, with necessary redactions to protect classified information. The term "intelligence community" is defined in section 3(4) of the National Security Act of 1947, necessary to protect properly classified information. Section 702(l) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to require assessments and reviews to be submitted in unclassified form, with the option of including a classified annex.
